question: Hello. I'll be just a minute...
answer: Why you going to the airport? Flying somewhere?

question: How'd you guess?
answer: Well, I saw your luggage, then when I noticed the airline ticket, I put two and two together. So where you heading?

question: Aspen.
answer: Oh, you're gonna love it. I hear California's beautiful this time of year. Mary looks back out the window and Lloyd sneaks another glance. Name's Christmas. Lloyd Christmas.

question: I'm Mary.
answer: Uh, this isn't my real job, you know. It's only temporary.

question: Oh?
answer: Yeah, you see, my friend Harry and I are saving up our money so we can open our own pet store.

question: That's nice.
answer: I got worms.

question: I beg your pardon?
answer: That's what we're gonna call it

question: Aren't ants quiet, too?
answer: Uh... well, sure but they aren't half as affectionate. And if you cut an ant's head off, it won't grow back.

question: I see.
answer: And best of all, worm farming is a seventy-five-thousand-dollar-a-year industry. I wouldn't mind having a piece of that pie, if you know what I mean. What's the matter? Little tense about the flight?

question: Something like that.
answer: It's really nothing to worry about, Mary. Statistically, they say you're more likely to get killed on the way to the airport. You know, like in a head-on crash, or something.

question: Um, Lloyd, could please keep your eyes on the road.
answer: Good thinking. There's a lot of bad rivers out there.

question: Here you go.
answer: Keep it. It was my pleasure. Relax, Mary. Just get trashed and pass out. You'll be there before you know it.

question: Thanks Lloyd. And good luck with your worms.
answer: Drive around me, you pinhead! Damn! You can't do this! I'll lose my job!

question: I got fired again.
answer: I don't mean to be harsh, Harry, but let's face it, you are one pathetic loser. No offense.

question: None taken. Were you shitcanned, too?
answer: Of course not. I quit.

question: Why'd you quit?
answer: I had a hunch Arnie was gonna fire me.

question: Why didn't you wait and see if your suspicions were well-founded?
answer: Winners control their own destiny, Har.

question: You know, the thing that really chaps my ass is that I just spent my life savings turning my van into a poodle. The alarm alone cost me two hundred.
answer: Big deal. That car's an old bomb anyway.

question: What are you talking about? It's only six years old.
answer: That's forty-two in dog years.

question: What's with the briefcase?
answer: It's a love memento.

question: Huh?
answer: The most beautiful woman alive. Her name was Mary. I drove her to the airport. Sparks flew, emotions ran high, breasts heaved. She left this case in the terminal and flew to Aspen and out of my life. End of story.

question: What's in it?
answer: DO you really expect me to go snooping around in someone else's private property?

question: Why not?
answer: It's locked. Friend or foe?

question: Can't recognize them. Could be student loan thugs again, or the IRS, or maybe somebody pissed off about that case of Girl Scout cookies you bounced a check on.
answer: Hey, I ordered Mystic Mint. The little swindlers gave me Peanut Butter Praline.

question: Well, whoever they are, they look serious. One of them's even wearing plaid.
answer: That's a hostile pattern. I say we bail and get down to unemployment. Blew it? For your information, we only missed three days in two months.

question: Give me what's left of our dough. I'll go to the corner and buy a few necessities. What's cheaper, Thunderbird or Night Train?
answer: Get Robitussin it's a better buzz.

question: Excuse me, little old lady, do you have change for a dollar? Well could you do me a favor and guard this while I go break a dollar? My wallet's locked in this machine.
answer: Where's the booze?

question: It's gone. I got robbed by Grandma Walton. She got my wallet, too. Come on, man, cheer up. We've been own before. I'm sure we'll land on our heads somewhere.
answer: It gets worse, Lloyd. My parakeet Petey he's... he's dead.

question: Oh man, I'm sorry, Harry. What happened?
answer: His head fell off.

question: His head fell off?
answer: Yeah, he was pretty old.

question: I don't suppose he had a warranty...?
answer: Nah, I bought him used.

question: That's it! I've had it with this ump! We don't have food, we don't have jobs, our pets' heads are falling off, we're surrounded by roving gangs of larcenous old
answer: Okay, calm down.

question: No I won't calm down. What the hell are we doing here anyway, Harry? We've got to get out of this town.
answer: Yeah, and go where?

question: I'll tell you where
answer: Aspen?

question: That's right, Aspen.
answer: I don't know, Lloyd, the French are assholes.

question: Let me ask you something
answer: What are you talking about, Lloyd? His head fell off. Wait a second, I know what you're up to. You just wanna go to Aspen so you can find that girl who lost her briefcase and you need me to drive you there.

question: That's bullshit. I'll drive. And what's so wrong about going someplace where we know someone who can plug us into the social pipeline?
answer: I don't know, Lloyd. I think we should stay here, hunt for jobs, and keep saving money for the worm store. I'm getting a little sick and tired of always running from creditors.

question: You know what I'm sick and tired of, Harry? I'm sick and tired of having to eek my way through life. I'm sick and tired of being a nobody. But most of all, I'm sick and tired of having nobody.
answer: Come on, Lloyd. Give us a kiss.

question: On the other hand, maybe you're right, Harry. Maybe we should stay here and try our luck in bankruptcy court. With all those lawsuits against us, I'm sure we'll win at least one. It could be a boost to our egos.
answer: Petey, I made a promise to you once, man... ...and I'll be damned if I can remember what it was.

question: Well, we're finally doing it. Do you realize that in all the years we've known each other, this is the first time we've done this together.
answer: Been run out of town?

question: Taken a trip. Why'd you do that?
answer: What?

question: Take your seatbelt off.
answer: Because we just cleared the danger zone.

question: Huh?
answer: Don't you know anything, Lloyd? Ninety percent of all accidents happen within five miles of home. We've already traveled 6.3 miles.

question: Well what about the people who live around here? What if we got into an accident with one of them?
answer: Where'd you get those?

question: Bought 'em when we filled up.
answer: Lloyd, I thought we agreed to confer on all expenditures. We're on a tight budget, remember?

question: This didn't come out of our travel fund. I was able to scrape up twenty- five bucks before we left. You know, so we could live in style.
answer: Where'd you get twenty-five extra bucks?

question: I sold some stuff to Billy in 4-C.
answer: You mean the blind kid?

question: That's right.
answer: What did you sell him, Lloyd?

question: Just some odds and ends.
answer: Specifically?

question: Oh, a few baseball cards, a sack of marbles, Petey, three comic books a second, are you telling me you sold my dead bird to a blind kid? Well who else was I gonna sell it to?
answer: But Lloyd, Petey didn't even have a head.

question: How far have we gone?
answer: According to this map, about an inch and a half.

question: Shit. We're gonna need a smaller map or we'll never get there. We don't have enough gas money.
answer: Relax. We have more than enough.

question: I believe you're wrong, Lloyd.
answer: And I believe I'm right, Harry.

question: I still say wrong, Lloyd.
answer: How much you wanna bet?

question: I don't bet.
answer: What do you mean you don't bet?

question: I mean I don't gamble, you know that. Never have and never will.
answer: Oh, bull. I'll bet you our next meal that I can get you gambling before the day's out.

question: There's no way, Lloyd. You can't do it.
answer: I'll give you three-to-one odds. That's three feedbags if you win, against only one if you lose.

question: You're wasting your money, Lloyd. I already told you, I don't gamble.
answer: Okay, five-to-one I can get you gambling before the day's out.

question: Sorry, pal, no way.
answer: Make it ten-to-one. Harry sticks out his hand.

question: You got yourself a bet, sucker!
answer: What's the soup du jour? Sounds tasty. I'll have a bowl.

question: Actually, this chocolate milk isn't mixed very well. Could you please bring me a spoon?
answer: Uh-oh...

question: What's the matter?
answer: You spilled the salt. That's bad luck. We're driving across the country and the last thing we need is bad luck. Quick, toss a handful of salt over your right shoulder.

question: What for?
answer: Because that's good luck. Or was it the left shoulder?

question: It was a terrible accident, Sir. Believe me, I would never do anything to offend a man of your size. Please accept my most sincere apology.
answer: You gonna eat that?

question: Um... the thought had crossed my mind.
answer: Still want it?

question: Well if you'd stop picking fights with the locals... Wait a second. I think I just had an idea. Follow me... Excuse me, gentlemen, I'd just like to apologize for that unpleasant scene a little earlier.
answer: Huh?

question: What I'm trying to say is, my friend and I would like to buy you guys a round of beers, just to bury the hatchet.
answer: Make it four boiler-makers.

question: Whatever you want, sir. I'll have the waitress send them over. Oh, and fellas hope to see you again down the road.
answer: Lloyd, what are you doing? You know we can't afford to buy them drinks.

question: Um, Sea Bass and the fellas offered to pick up our check. They said just add this to their tab. Well, if that guy at the table over there is Sea Bass...
answer: Oh, and put these on there, too.

question: I just wish we could've seen Sea Bass's face when he got the bill.
answer: I hope we never have to.

question: Don't worry. That fish-head is probably half-way to Providence by now.
answer: I hope so.

question: Hey, stop the car. I gotta take a whiz.
answer: Are you crazy? I'm not stopping now. What if they figure out we went the other way. They'll be on us in no time.

question: But I gotta go. What am I supposed to do?
answer: Hold it.

question: I can't hold it. I'm about to explode.
answer: Well... just take a whiz in an empty beer bottle. There's a couple on the floor in the back seat.

question: Are you serious?
answer: Yes, I'm serious. I'm not stopping now. We could get killed. Lloyd SIGHS. He takes an EMPTY BEER BOTTLE from the back seat and UNZIPS his fly. Suddenly we hear a PEEING SOUND. Then:

question: Uh-oh...
answer: What's the matter?

question: The bottle's almost full and I'm still going.
answer: Well stop going.

question: I can't stop once I already started, you know that. Quick, get me another bottle. Jesus, be careful! You almost went off the road.
answer: I'm sorry, Lloyd. I'm doing the best I can.

question: Here, hold this.
answer: What are you, a goddamn camel?

question: Pull over!
answer: Huh?

question: PULL OVER!
answer: No, it's a Cardigan! But thanks for noticing! Jesus, what is this, the fashion police?

question: License and registration, please. You know, you fellas were all over the road back there.
answer: Yes, sir, we had a little... ifficulty in the car.

question: Uh-huh. Have you boys been doing a little rinking maybe?
answer: No, sir.

question: Then what's that?
answer: Oh, that's nothing, sir.

question: I don't know, Lloyd, I feel a little sleazy staying here when we're not even engaged.
answer: Hey, it's the only motel that charges by the hour. We can't afford anything else. Yep, this sure is the life. Cold beer, a hot tube, and fuzzy pink sheets... You know, there's only one thing that could make this moment any better.

question: What's that?
answer: If you had a nice set of knockers.

question: That's two things, Lloyd.
answer: Right now I'd settle for one.

question: I don't know, Lloyd, these places just don't do it for me. Brings back too many memories.
answer: What happened, Harry? Some little filly break your heart?

question: Nah, it was a girl. Fraida Felcher. We stayed at a place like this once No-Tell Motel out on Route 31.
answer: Felcher? You mean the babe who worked for the tractor company?

question: The same. We had this incredibly romantic time. Boy, I thought we'd be together forever.
answer: That's cold, Har. Give you any reason?

question: The boys are holed-up in a little love nest for the night. I think they're a couple of fucking weirdos.
answer: What in hell are those guys up to? Is it possible that they're Feds?

question: Unlikely from what I've seen.
answer: I don't like this one goddamn bit, Mental. You and Shay were supposed to grab that bag so we could end this shit. Now I don't know what the hell's going on.

question: Hold on a second, Mr. Andre... Sorry, boss. You were saying...?
answer: Look, Mental, just find out what they're up to. I want to know who these guys are.

question: You're it.
answer: You're it.

question: You're it. Quitsies.
answer: Anti-quitsies. You're it. Quitsies. No anti-quitsies. No startsies.

question: Refresh my memory on something, Lloyd
answer: Well the first thing we do is take a good deep breath of that famous Aspenese air.

question: Fresh, huh?
answer: The freshest. They say on any day of the week you can smell a moose-fart ten miles away.

question: Wow... talk about paradise. And after we're finished breathing, what next, Lloyd?
answer: Then we make a splash on the social scene. Harry, look the golden arches. Pull over, I'm starving. CUT TO:

question: About this social scene how do you expect a couple mutts like us to make a splash in the land of pedigrees when we don't even have any money?
answer: Look, once we drop the briefcase off to Mary, she'll be so grateful she'll plug us right into the party circuit. After that, we do a little of the ski

question: Where'd you hear that?
answer: Some bum down at unemployment.

question: I don't know, Lloyd.
answer: What's the matter?

question: Money does terrible things to people. I mean, we could lose our friendship.
answer: Yeah? So? Hey, wait a second. Hold everything.

question: What?
answer: Aren't you forgetting something? Back at Mickey D's? A little matter you might've overlooked...?

question: What?
answer: My change.

question: It's a fruit.
answer: It's a vegetable.

question: I'm telling you, it's a fruit.
answer: And I happen to know it's a vegetable.

question: Tell you what, why don't we leet an impartial judge decide.
answer: Fine with me.

question: Hey, Mr. Mentalino, settle our bet
answer: Okay, Harry, my turn. Let 'er rip. Hmmm... full-bodied, delicate bouquet, aged to perfection will rip no fart before it's time. Come on, Marquis of Dingleberry's rules

question: And...?
answer: Kit-Kat bar.

question: You're the best, man. Okay, my turn.
answer: Where are your manners, Harry? We have a guest.

question: Come on, Mr. Mentalino. Let one fly. It's only a buck. I'll do one if you will.
answer: Okay, you go first.

question: No, you go first.
answer: No, you go first.

question: Have some water. It'll help. Aw, shucks, that's right. Water just makes it worse... It's Mental. I'm just sitting down to a nice meal with our boys.
answer: Good work. What did you find out so far?

question: Nothing yet, but I'm gonna shake 'em own for information at lunch. Then I'm gonna kill 'em for dessert.
answer: Well eat fast, time's running out.

question: That really wasn't very polite of him, was it? Maybe we should loosen the screws of his chair.
answer: Harry Dunne, I'm surprised at you. Perhaps it's about time you brushed

question: You mean like 'turn the other cheek?'
answer: No, I mean like 'an eye for an eye.' Hand me those peppers the atomic ones.

question: I can't believe it...
answer: Life is a fragile thing, Har. One minute you're chewing on a burger; the next minute you're dead meat.

question: But he blamed me. You heard him. Those were his last words.
answer: If you don't count that gurgling sound. Hey, relax, man, I'm just as responsible as you are we both slipped him the peppers and look at me, I on't feel guilty at all.

question: Small comfort coming from a man who sells dead birds to blind kids.
answer: That's ridiculous. You probably won't live to see forty.

question: You mean he was poisoned?
answer: Waitress says he was with a couple of younger guys. They're the ones who called the ambulance then they hit the road.

question: Any idea where they were going?
answer: A witness at the next table thought he heard them say they were driving to France. We got a report they were seen heading west on I-80 toward Colorado.

question: Get a make on the vehicle?
answer: Yes, sir. They were driving an '84 poodle.

question: An '84 what?
answer: Well it might have been a wire-haired terrier, Detective. They're very similar in appearance.

question: Let's get off and crash at a motel before I crash into one. I need a crib fast.
answer: Sorry, Har. We're gonna have to hold out. Seems we misjudged our expense allocation. If we pay for a motel we won't have enough for gas.

question: What happened to the dough?
answer: We over-leveraged.

question: On what?
answer: I sprung for Mr. Chili Pepper's last meal. Felt it was the least we could o after we deep-sixed him.

question: Wait a second one burger put us over budget?
answer: The slob ordered a double-bacon eluxe and a chocolate malt.

question: Oh. So what are we gonna do?
answer: Drive. We've only got ten more hours. We can take turns.

question: Come on, wake up. You pay, I'll pump. Skis, huh?
answer: That's right.

question: Great. They yours?
answer: Uh-huh..

question: Both of 'em?
answer: Um, yeah.

question: Cool.
answer: Excuse me, you're spraying everywhere.

question: That's a lot of luggage for a little vacation.
answer: Actually, I'm moving to Aspen. I've got to get away from my boyfriend.

question: Here, this is a little loose. Allow me... Look, um, maybe when I get to Aspen we can meet up... you know, for hot chocolate or something.
answer: Why not? You seem pretty harmless. I'll give you my number. Just let me find a pen. I know I have one here somewhere...

question: Look, why don't you just tell it to me, I've got a good memory.
answer: Are you sure you won't forget?

question: Positive please hurry.
answer: Is something wrong? Okay, my number is 652-2553. Oh, wait a second, that's my old number. It's so funny how your mind god sakes, give me the damn number! Look, man, if you're gonna get pushy you can just forget it!

question: Um, yeah could you do it the other way around?
answer: You've got some serious explaining to o, young man.

question: Look, Harry, I told you what happened, now drop it.
answer: Sure thing, Lloyd. I promise not to mention another word about you being in a bathroom stall with a six-foot, five-inch trucker with his pants own.

question: That's a low blow, man.
answer: Not at that height it's not.

question: Listen, bud, if you're trying to imply that I'm that thought look, we're almost in Colorado.
answer: I think it's about time we pull over and change seats. I've been driving for nine straight hours I don't have the energy to start a new state.

question: Hey, I picked you up a Beef Jerky... Boy, some guys just weren't cut out for life on the road. Hey, Mr. Sleepy Head, welcome back.
answer: How long have I been out?

question: I'd say a good five hours, anyway.
answer: Great. We must be getting real close, huh?

question: Should be. I've been averaging about ninety miles an hour all night.
answer: Good man.

question: Boy, I'll tell you, this is one angerous highway. You wouldn't believe all the road pizza two dead ogs, a couple of rabbits, a snake and some big thing I couldn't even recognize.
answer: That's awful. Did you see them get hit or were they already lying there?

question: I hit 'em.
answer: Funny. I expected the Rocky Mountains to be a little rockier than this.

question: I was thinking the same thing. That John Denver's some full of shit, huh? I must say, Des Moines sure is a pretty little town.
answer: Yeah, it really is. Wait a minute when did you visit Des Moines?

question: Last night. We drove through it.
answer: What are you talking about? You were snoring like a baby when we went through Des Moines.

question: Hello? Hello? Anybody home? Rise and shine.
answer: Uh, Lloyd, refresh my memory

question: In our country it does, yes.
answer: Then perchance you can explain to me why the sun is in our face at 7:30 in the morning when we're heading west.

question: I'm only human, Harry. Anybody can make a mistake. Come on, man, pull yourself together.
answer: You know, I got half a mind to just jump on the bus to Europe and say goodbye to your ugly mug forever.

question: You can't take a bus to Europe, dodo.
answer: Oh yeah? Why not?

question: You don't have a passport. Come on, stop being a baby about this. Okay, so we back-tracked a tad.
answer: A tad? Lloyd, you drove almost a sixth of the way across the country in the wrong direction. Now we don't have enough money to get to Aspen, we on't have enough money to get home, we don't have enough to eat, we don't have enough to sleep!

question: Well it doesn't do any good having you sitting there on your butt whining about it. If we're gonna get out of this hole, we're gonna have to dig ourselves out.
answer: You know, you're absolutely right, Lloyd.

question: Where you going?
answer: Home. I'm walking home.

question: You can't be serious.
answer: Why not? We're probably only five miles away. Look, man... I'm sorry. I never should have let you talk me into this in the first place. You've got a good reason to goo a beautiful girl's waiting for you. But let's face it, Lloyd, there's nothing waiting for me in Aspen. There's nothing waiting for me anywhere.

question: Tell me something, Harry. Would you really have kept going home if I hadn't come back to get you?
answer: Well let me put it this way, Lloyd

question: We were never Cub Scouts.
answer: Exactly. What the hell is this? There's a coffin in the back!

question: Relax, it's empty.
answer: I don't give a shit. I'm not driving anywhere with a casket. You know I'm superstitious calm down. We'll dump it off first chance we get.

question: Isn't this wonderful? What more could a couple of single guys like us ask for?
answer: How about food and shelter?

question: You're so materialistic. Why don't we get down to business and eliver the briefcase to Mary. Who knows, maybe she'll invite us in for tea and a strumpet or two?
answer: Jolly good idea, chap. And where oes the lovely young lady reside?

question: Um... good question.
answer: Well what's her last name? We'll look it up in the phone book.

question: Hmmmm... You know, I don't believe I caught that either.
answer: What about the briefcase, Lloyd? There must've been a name on it, right?

question: Come to think of it, there is. It's engraved right into the leather.
answer: What is it?

question: Samsonite spelled just like it sounds.
answer: Any soup left?

question: A little. Shall we share it?
answer: Please.

question: Mmmm mmmm good...
answer: Hey, you got something stuck in your front teeth. Lloyd picks a small speck out of his mouth and studies it.

question: Hmmm... looks like an old piece of Beef Jerky.
answer: Wanna split it?

question: You're pathetic. Get your own.
answer: I'm freezing my ass off, Lloyd.

question: Roll up your window.
answer: It is rolled up.

question: Then I guess the damn anti-cold system isn't working. You really should get it fixed if we're gonna live here all winter.
answer: What anti-cold system?

question: Right here the A/C button. I put it on full blast about an hour ago and, if anything, the car's getting colder. What are you going out there for?
answer: To warm up.

question: What are you worrying about now?
answer: I'm worried about how you're gonna survive the pummeling I'm about to give you.

question: Huh? Harry, calm down! You're acting like a wild animal!
answer: Get over here and take your medicine, Lloyd!

question: Sorry, doc, I can't take medicine. I'm a Christian Scientist! What are you doing?
answer: Something I should've done a long time ago. This stupid thing has been the root of our problems all along.

question: Don't do anything foolish, Harry.
answer: Foolish? This is the most sensible thing I've done in years. I'm gonna toss this goddamn curse right into that river. Lloyd starts to follow after Harry.

question: You're making a big mistake, Harry! I'll never forgive you for this! Harry, hold up! Things are gonna get better, I promise! In fact, I think
answer: You're bluffing.

question: No I'm not, man look.
answer: That's a filling, you liar! I used to have a life! A miserable one, but a life, nonetheless!

question: Okay, here's the plan
answer: Sounds good.

question: And we'll keep track of the money we spend with IOUs.
answer: We'll be meticulous right down to the last penny.

question: That way, whatever we borrow we can pay back.
answer: Absolutely. We're good for it.

question: You know, as soon as we get jobs.
answer: It'll come right out of our first paycheck.

question: Mary? You awake? I brought you some tea. I thought it might help you relax.
answer: Thank you. Yech! What's in this, whiskey?

question: Uh, sorry... that one's mine. Feeling any better, honey?
answer: Just knowing that Melvin's out there, being held by God knows who... It's all my fault. I should've been there.

question: Bullshit. You can't blame yourself for this. If you'd been there they would've taken you, too.
answer: Maybe we should just pay them the money again and get this thing over

question: Now Mary, everything that can be done is being done. You've got to stop torturing yourself.
answer: What am I supposed to do? Go about my life as if everything were fine?

question: Oh god, it's really true. Last night I thought I might've been dreaming.
answer: It's no dream, Har. We finally cracked the big time.

question: And it was so simple. All it took was somebody else's money. You know, Lloyd, I think you might've gone a little overboard with the spending today.
answer: What's the big deal? We're gonna pay it all back anyway, right?

question: Sure, but do you really think you needed to buy those two surfboards?
answer: Surfboards? I thought those were beginner's skis. This suddenly makes sense to Harry.

question: Ahhh. I was wondering why you had those bindings put on them.
answer: Where'd this come from?

question: I bought it.
answer: What for?

question: I like the feel of it against my skin... ...I mean, you know, when a woman's wearing it.
answer: Harry, how many women do you know who wear a size XXL?

question: Look, leave me alone. I'm rich now. I'm supposed to have a few eccentricities.
answer: Enter, parlez vous!

question: Enter, parlez vous!
answer: I brought you your newspaper and some champagne, gentlemen. Unfortunately, we didn't seem to have the, um, label you requested.

question: All out of Boone's Farm, huh?
answer: You have a rapier wit, sir. I took the liberty of bringing a comparable substitute

question: Guess it'll have to do, slugger, eh?
answer: Thank you so much, sir.

question: Oh, one more thing
answer: Cocktail hour has commenced! Hey, later on what do you say we...? Lloyd... you okay?

question: Harry, it's her.
answer: Who?

question: Mary with the briefcase. This is her... Mary Swanson...
answer: Come on, Cinderella, it's time to get you ready for the ball...

question: This should cover a couple plates.
answer: I'm kind of hungry, Lloyd. What if we want seconds?

question: Put us down for four plates, my good man. I'm getting nervous, Harry.
answer: relax, Lloyd. These people are just like you and me.

question: What are you talking about? They're educated, well-bred, charming, and sophisticated.
answer: So what? We can be sophistica holy shit, would you look at the fun bags on that hose hound.

question: Don't do this to me, Harry. I'm already a wreck. What if Mary oesn't like me?
answer: Look, let's just go saddle up to the bar and down a couple bowls of loudmouth soup. A little booze'll bring back that old Lloyd Christmas over-confidence.

question: Two martinis, straight up. As Harry and Lloyd silently take in the party, a BEAUTIFUL RED HEAD reaches between them for a cocktail napkin, then walks away. Shut up, Harry.
answer: I didn't say anything.

question: Yeah, well I know what you were gonna say and I'm telling you to shut up in advance.
answer: How do you know what I was gonna say?

question: I read you like a book.
answer: Okay, if you read me like a book then what was I gonna say?

question: Two more, please.
answer: Lloyd, I've never seen you this uptight. You've gotta chill out.

question: I can't help it. This is a very important night for me. Harry, have you ever wondered why you and I never have long-term girlfriends?
answer: What are you talking about? I went out with Fraida Felcher for two and a half weeks.

question: That was a fluke. The reason we never have long-term girlfriends is because of one thing
answer: That's crazy. We live for the C word.

question: I'm talking bout commitment.
answer: Oh.

question: Well I'm ready for commitment, Harry. The first time I laid eyes on Mary Swanson, I knew she was the one. Some things you feel in your heart, other things you feel in your groin. This girl makes me feel it all in the heart. Oh shit, there she is.
answer: Wow. You weren't kidding, Lloyd. She's an angel. Well, what are you waiting for? Get over there and talk to her.

question: She's gonna think I'm some kind of psycho when she realizes how far I came just to see her.
answer: You have her briefcase she's gonna be thrilled to see you.

question: And then what? She'll take it back and that'll be it. I'm a nobody.
answer: Look, man, you just drove two thousand miles to see this girl. Don't quit on the last fifty feet.

question: Wait a second, I have an idea. You go over and introduce yourself. That way you can build me up so when I come along I won't have to brag about myself. Tell her I'm good-looking and I'm rich and I have a rapist's wit.
answer: I can't tell her you're good looking, Lloyd she's got eyes.

question: Please Harry, I'm appealing to you as one loser to another. Just build me up and then give me a signal to come over. Please.
answer: All right. But you're gonna owe me a big one for this. Nice set of hooters you got there.

question: All right. But you're gonna owe me a big one for this. Nice set of hooters you got there.
answer: I beg your pardon?

question: The owls. They're beautiful.
answer: Oh. Yeah. Are you a bird lover?

question: Well, I used to have a parakeet, but my main area of expertise is canines that's dogs to the layperson.
answer: Thanks. I love dogs, too. So how

question: Oh, I've trained them, bathed them, clipped them; I've even bred them.
answer: Really? Any unusual breeding?

question: Nah, mostly just doggie-style. But one time we successfully mated a Bulldog and a Shitzu.
answer: Really? That's weird.

question: Harry Dunne. Pleasure meeting you both.
answer: I saw you come in earlier, Mr. Dunne. I was hoping we'd get a chance to meet.

question: You were?
answer: That tuxedo I love a man with a sense of humor. So does Mary.

question: Oh, I don't know. You see, my friend your friends for one day. You and Mary will have a ball. Um... well... I don't know. You see, the thing is... sure.
answer: How come you didn't call me over?

question: Relax, you're golden. I got you a ate with her tomorrow.
answer: Wha... you... I... it's... I love you, man. I love you!

question: Okay, get a grip, Lloyd. You're making a scene.
answer: This calls for a toast! You're gonna be my best man, Har, I mean it. It was always between you and my future wife's brother, but you just earned a seat at the head table, pal.

question: Maybe it was just a coincidence.
answer: Don't be stupid. It's a message, plain and simple

question: But how could anybody off a bird with a cork?
answer: These guys arent' just anybody. They're good. Look what they did to Mental. He was the best, and yet he fell right into their web.

question: But the bastards already got our money. What the hell more could they want?
answer: I don't know, god damn it!

question: Mrs. Christmas... Mary Christmas... Mrs. Mary Christmas. You
answer: Sounds nice, Lloyd, but don't you think you may be jumping the gun a little? I mean, who knows, when you get to know her, you may find out she's not your type.

question: Impossible. I know my type when I see it. Now let me get this straight, she wants me to meet her at the Avalanche Bar and Grill on Main Street?
answer: That's what she said. Ten o'clock sharp.

question: Time out. Where are going ressed like that.
answer: I, uh, thought while you were making your love connection I'd try my luck on the slopes.

question: You mean you're gonna go out in public dressed in tights?
answer: These aren't tights. They're fashionable Euro-trash ski trousers.

question: But you can see the outline of your who-who.
answer: Really?

question: Turn sideways. Actually, it's just a tiny little lump. No one will ever notice.
answer: You're right. I can't go out dressed like this. Sorry I'm late. It's a bitch driving a clutch with these things.

question: Beautiful day, huh, Harry?
answer: Glorious.

question: God, it feels so good to get up here. I haven't been outdoors much in the last couple of weeks.
answer: Why not?

question: There's been... family problems. I on't want to bore you with them.
answer: Thanks. Oh, look... frost.

question: Are you okay?
answer: Sure. I do this all the time... CUT TO: See ya at the bottom... Hi. Say, kids, you wouldn't happen to have a cup of warm water, would you?

question: Better make it quarter to eight. I've got a few things to take care of first. Mary Dunne... Mrs. Mary Dunne... Got a nice ring to it.
answer: Some best man.

question: It doesn't make any sense, Lloyd. She told me ten o'clock sharp. Are you sure you went to the right bar?
answer: Believe me, it was the right place.

question: I have a hard time believing that, Lloyd. The girl said she couldn't wait to see you again. Wait a minute...
answer: What?

question: It just occurred to me. She must've meant ten o'clock at night.
answer: Do ya think...?

question: Of course! Why would she have you meet her at a bar at ten in the morning?
answer: I just figured she was a raging alcoholic.

question: Boy, aren't we a couple of beauties?
answer: I knew there was an explanation. And here I thought she was standing me up.

question: That'll teach you to jump to conclusions. Anyway, since you have your night all
answer: Will you join me in a good luck toast before you head out?

question: Sure thing, pal. Whatever you think will help your chances.
answer: Pretty snazzed out for a movie, aren't you?

question: Uh... it's for mature audiences. I on't wanna chance getting turned away at the door.
answer: I see. To my friend Harry the matchmaker.

question: Mmmmm...
answer: Hi. Come on in. Make yourself at home. I'm almost ready. Just give me one more minute. Are you in there, Harry?

question: Be right out.
answer: I hope you're not using the toilet. It's broken.

question: Huh?
answer: It doesn't flush.

question: Um, no, I was just... shaving.
answer: Shaving?

question: Yeah! I was running a little late. Thought this would save time.
answer: Okay. Well I'll be in the living room whenever you're ready.

question: Come on, flush, you bastard...
answer: Yes...?

question: Yes...?
answer: Hi. Don't you remember me?

question: Um... I'm not really...
answer: South Bend. I drove you to the airport last week.

question: Oh my god. Lloyd, right?
answer: You remembered.

question: What are you doing in Aspen?
answer: I brought you your briefcase You left it at the airport so I picked it up for you.

question: You're the one who took my briefcase?
answer: Yeah, it's back at my hotel room. Come on, let's take a ride. I'll give it to you.

question: Wait right here. Harry, what are you doing in there?
answer: Uh... just cleaning my teeth. Give me a minute, Mary, I'll be right with you.

question: Sorry, but something important's come up and I have to run out. It's sort of an emergency. I'll explain later.
answer: But Mary --

question: --I'm really sorry, Harry. I promise we'll do this another time.
answer: Great...

question: ..So anyway, as soon as I got to town I tried to look you up but I idn't know your last name.
answer: I don't believe it. You really have it.

question: 'Course I have it. When Lloyd Christmas drives a woman to the airport, he makes sure she gets all her luggage, no matter what he has to
answer: This is incredible. You mean to say you drove two thousand miles just for me?

question: Well... no... I mean, you know, there were other reasons... Actually, yeah, I guess I did.
answer: That is the sweetest thing I've ever heard.

question: Look, Mary, I know this may seem a little sudden but I've given it a lot of thought
answer: Oh... I thought I heard you talking to someone.

question: Mary...
answer: Maybe I should be going now.

question: No, that's not what Imeant. I meant... I really like you, Mary. I like you a lot. I'm gonna ask you something flat out and I want you to answer me honestly
answer: Lloyd, that's difficult to say. I

question: --I asked you to be honest, Mary.
answer: But Lloyd, I really can't --

question: --Come on, give it to me straight. I rove a long way to see you, the least you can do is level with me. What are my chances?
answer: Not good.

question: You mean not good, like one out of a hundred?
answer: I'd say more like one out of a million.

question: So you're telling me there's a chance?
answer: Nicholas... what are you doing here?

question: Shut up!
answer: Uh, sir, about the briefcase, I want you to know, my friend Harry and I have every intention of reimbursing you.

question: Open that damn thing! Mary opens the briefcase and a pile of WHITE, CRUMPLED-UP BALLS OF PAPER fall out along with a few packets of hundreds. What the hell's this? Where's all the money?
answer: That's as good as money, sir. Those are our IOUs. You can add them up yourself. Every penny's accounted for.

question: You're fucking dead!
answer: Now don't do anything hasty, man.

question: Yeah, we used to be best friends.
answer: Until he turned into a backstabber.

question: Me a backstabber? You got a lot of nerve. I saw her first.
answer: Hey, I couldn't help it if she found me irresistable.

question: But you knew how crazy I was about her.
answer: Yeah, and you knew how crazy I was about Fraida Felcher, but that didn't stop you, did it?

question: What are you talking about?
answer: Don't deny it, Lloyd. Fraida told me the whole sordid story.

question: Look... I was gonna tell you about that. It was gonna be mentioned at the reading of my will. I swear, you can ask my lawyer.
answer: Well I guess we both learned a little something about each other, didn't we?

question: You said it, pal. Maybe we're not as good friends as we thought we were.
answer: Guess not.

question: I mean, if one beautiful girl could rip us apart like this, then it seems our friendship isn't worth a damn. Maybe we should call it quits right here.
answer: Just tell me where to sign, bud.

question: Just tell me where to sign, bud.
answer: Okay, which one of you losers wants to die first?

question: I wouldn't pull that trigger if I were you.
answer: Why not? It'll look like just another Aspen love triangle. You caught the two of them in bed, handcuffed them to the post, murdered them, and killed yourself.

question: Except you're forgetting one minor etail.
answer: What's that?

question: If you kill us, you'd be killing yourself.
answer: Huh?

question: You see, philosophers believe that we're all really just tiny pieces of one huge universal being. In other words, I am you and you are me, so if you were to kill us you'd be committing suicide, you unenlightened
answer: --Shut up!

question: She's something, ain't she, Har?
answer: You were right, Lloyd. She was efinitely worth the trip.

question: Guess we have to admit it, she was too good for us.
answer: Hey, Barney...

question: Look, we just wanted to say that we appreciate all you did for us during our stay.
answer: And we're, um, sorry about the money we gave you turning out to be phony.
